explanation: Correct. MISRA C:2023 Rule 2.2 forbids executed operations whose removal would not affect program behaviour. In the provided build configuration mhd_assert is defined as a no-op (#define mhd_assert(ignore) ((void)0)). All call sites like mhd_assert(...) therefore reduce to an expression-statement that performs no observable action. Those statements are executed by the abstract machine but have no effect and can be removed without changing program behaviour (aside from micro-timing differences), so they meet the rule’s definition of dead code. Note: one can mention the subtle counter‑argument from Rule 2.2 Note 1 (timing can be part of behaviour) — in extremely timing‑sensitive embedded contexts removal of even no‑ops could change behaviour — but nothing in the scenario indicates such timing-dependence is being relied upon. On the facts given, Agent A’s report is correct: the project contains dead code arising from the disabled mhd_assert macro.
